meta.name: Description

head.title: Contribution of Interstitial Boron in a Boron-Incorporated Palladium Catalyst Toward Formate Oxidation in an Alkaline Direct Formate Fuel Cell | ACS Catalysis

meta.content: Contribution of Interstitial Boron in a Boron-Incorporated Palladium Catalyst Toward Formate Oxidation in an Alkaline Direct Formate Fuel Cell

In this study, boron-incorporated palladium catalysts supported on carbon (PdBInc./C) were synthesized; they exhibited considerably improved catalytic activity for the oxidation of formate (HCOO–). Boron-induced lattice expansion and electronic modification of Pd were observed in this catalyst through various physicochemical analyses. Furthermore, the effective electronic modification between Pd and B was found to overcome the limitation due to the lattice expansion of Pd and the modification was confirmed from the downshift and broadening of the d-band center. The direction of electron transfer was observed from B to Pd. Based on the experimental results, it is possible to infer that PdBInc./C significantly contributes to the weakening of the hydrogen adsorption, which is regarded as a rate-determining step for the oxidation of HCOO–. As an anode electrode, PdBInc./C also showed an outstanding performance in a direct formate fuel cell owing to its modified electronic structure, which is considered an important property to facilitate hygroscopic fuel accessibility in a practical system.

div.span: Supporting Info (1)
SUBJECTS:

div.p:
In this study, boron-incorporated palladium catalysts supported on carbon (PdB
Inc.
/C) were synthesized; they exhibited considerably improved catalytic activity for the oxidation of formate (HCOO
–
). Boron-induced lattice expansion and electronic modification of Pd were observed in this catalyst through various physicochemical analyses. Furthermore, the effective electronic modification between Pd and B was found to overcome the limitation due to the lattice expansion of Pd and the modification was confirmed from the downshift and broadening of the d-band center. The direction of electron transfer was observed from B to Pd. Based on the experimental results, it is possible to infer that PdB
Inc.
/C significantly contributes to the weakening of the hydrogen adsorption, which is regarded as a rate-determining step for the oxidation of HCOO
–
. As an anode electrode, PdB
Inc.
/C also showed an outstanding performance in a direct formate fuel cell owing to its modified electronic structure, which is considered an important property to facilitate hygroscopic fuel accessibility in a practical system.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Palladium has been in the limelight as a versatile heterogeneous catalyst for hydrogenation, dehydrogenation, carbon–carbon bond formation, and oxidation reactions. Among its many electrochemical applications, Pd has specifically been reported as an outstanding electrocatalyst for organic molecule oxidation of compounds such as primary alcohols, formic acid, and formate (HCOO
–
).
(1−4)
According to several mechanistic studies of the formate oxidation reaction, decreasing the chemisorption strength of adsorbed species by modifying the electronic structure of Pd can contribute to an enhancement in the catalytic activity.
(5−8)
Binary and ternary Pd-metal-alloy catalysts have been reported to improve the oxidation activity not only through electronic modification but also by contributions from their oxophilic properties. In other words, many studies have aimed for a synergistic effect between electronic modification and oxophilic properties in such catalysts. However, it is not easy to distinguish between the causes of oxidation activity enhancement in these catalysts because the electronic interaction and the adsorbate–adsorbate interaction occur simultaneously.
(9−21)
Pd can interstitially contain a substantial amount of light elements such as hydrogen or boron, which can lead to an improvement in catalytic activities for hydrogenation,
(22)
organic molecule oxidation,
(7,22−29)
and oxygen reduction
(30,31)
reactions by excluding the adsorbate–adsorbate interaction from different adsorption sites. Light-element-incorporated Pd catalysts such as palladium hydride and palladium–boron have been extensively studied for various electrochemical reactions.
(7,23−31)
According to these studies, the Pd lattice is expanded by incorporating the light elements, which changes the electronic structure simultaneously. Most studies have consistently concluded that the adsorption strength of adsorbates weakens when such Pd catalysts are used; however, elucidation of a correlation between the direction of electron transfer and parameters such as adsorption strength of the adsorbed species, the direction of shift in the d-band center, and changes in the d-band width has been controversial.
(7,22−33)
Therefore, it is necessary to elucidate the relationship between heteroatom-doping-induced lattice expansion and the activity of Pd electrocatalysts.

In this study, boron was incorporated into the Pd lattice and synthesized on a carbon-supported catalyst (PdB
Inc.
/C); the role of boron in the oxidation of HCOO
–
in alkaline media was investigated through various physicochemical and electrochemical analysis. Furthermore, application of an as-developed Pd-based catalyst was attempted in a direct formate fuel cell operation. The superior contribution of boron in modification of the electronic structure of Pd, compared to that of palladium hydride in a previous study,
(24)
is elucidated.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Palladium catalysts supported on carbon were synthesized via the wet-chemical method with a dimethylamine borane complex (DMAB) as a reducing agent.
(24,27,29,33,34)
DMAB is a covalent compound, and its reduction mechanism with hydrolysis is
(35)
Boron-incorporated palladium (PdB
Inc.
) nanoparticles were synthesized using this reaction mechanism. Sodium tetrachloropalladate(II) (Na
2
PdCl
4
, Sigma-Aldrich, ≥99.99%) weighing 92.7 mg was added into a mixture of boric acid (which was added to suppress the hydrolysis of the reducing agent), ammonium fluoride (a complexing agent), and deionized water (18.2 MΩ cm) and then stirred to dissolve them completely. Subsequently, an ammonia solution was added to the mixture to adjust the pH to a weak alkaline level (8.5). After stirring the mixture for 10 min, degasification with bubbling nitrogen gas was conducted for at least 20 min. Subsequently, activated carbon (Vulcan XC-72 after HNO
3
treatment) was added with stirring for 10 min, and the mixture was sonicated for 1 h at 0 °C. The mixture was stirred additionally for 1 h at 0 °C and 20 mL of 0.1 M DMAB was added dropwise to it at a rate of 0.4 mL min
–1
with vigorous stirring for 2 h. Finally, after stirring the solution at room temperature for 1 h, the obtained PdB
Inc.
/C catalysts were thoroughly rinsed with deionized (DI) water and vacuum dried in an oven at 60 °C for 1 day. All catalysts were stored in a vacuum desiccator to inhibit contact with all oxidants.

In the physicochemical analysis, Pd and B contents of the synthesized catalyst were measured using an inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometer (ICP-AES, model ICP-IRIS, Thermo Jarrell Ash Co.) at the Korea Basic Science Institute (KBSI), Busan Center. The amount of Pd was measured to be 18.11 wt % (for the half-cell experiment) and 31.7 wt % (for the single-cell experiment), which included 5.63 and 7.09 atom % of boron, respectively. The particle sizes, diffractogram, and the line profile of the catalyst were analyzed by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM, Philips TECNA1F20) and field-emission transmission electron microscopy (FE-TEM, JEM-2100F, JEOL) at the Center for Research Facilities at Chonnam National University. X-ray diffraction (XRD, Miniflex II, Rigaku) analysis with Cu Kα (λ = 0.15406 nm) was also conducted to double check the crystal structures of PdB
Inc
., standard Pd, commercial Pd/C, and Pd/C
(24,29)
used in our previous study for comparison. The
d
-spacing and lattice parameter were calculated using the following equations
Pd/C was also analyzed for the comparison of physicochemical properties and catalytic activities of the Pd catalysts.

X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS; Thermo Fisher Scientific, Theta Prove AR-XPS system) was utilized to identify the electronic structure of the Pd catalysts at KBSI, Busan Center. The binding energies were calibrated by reference to the C 1s peak at 284.5 eV. The oxidation states and the lattice structure of these catalysts were analyzed using X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) with the 7D X-ray absorption fine structure (7D-XAFS) beamline at the Pohang Accelerator Laboratory (PAL). XAS data of the Pd K-edge were measured in a transmission mode from 24150 to 25300 eV by employing a double-crystal Si(111) monochromator in a step-scan mode. A Pd foil was simultaneously measured as a reference. Ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy (UPS, Thermo Fisher Scientific) was used to measure the work function of each catalyst. Since surface oxidation can interfere with the UPS analysis, the catalyst surface was etched with argon plasma during the analysis.

In the electrochemical analysis, all electrochemical experiments were performed with a three-electrode system using a potentiostat/galvanostat (Biologic, VSP). The ink consisted of 10 mg of the catalyst, 2.5 mL of DI water, 2.5 mL of dimethylformamide (DMF, Junsei), and 10 μg of a Nafion solution (Sigma-Aldrich, 10 wt %). For the cell, 40.8 μg cm
–2
of the catalyst (8.16 μg cm
–2
of Pd metal) was used as the working electrode by drop-casting 20 μL of well-dispersed catalyst ink on a rotating disk electrode (glassy carbon, 0.196 cm
2
). A Pt wire and a Hg/HgO electrode filled with 1 M potassium hydroxide were used as the counter and reference electrodes, respectively. A cleaning process utilizing cyclic voltammetry (CV) was carried out to remove impurities on the catalyst surfaces, scanning from 0.916 to 0.234 V vs. Hg/HgO in 1 M KOH saturated with N
2
at a scan rate of 100 mV s
–1
for 50 cycles. CVs were collected for each catalyst at a scan rate of 20 mV s
–1
to show their characteristics. The electrode surface area (ECSA) was calculated using equations presented in previous studies
(7,24,36,37)
where ∫
i
O
dν is the measured Pd–O peak area from CV; ν is the scan rate (mV s
–1
);
S
is the RDE area (cm
2
);
m
is the loading amount on RDE (g); χ is the fraction for Pd metal; and
Q
PdO
upd
is the charge required to reduce a monolayer of O
upd
on the Pd surface = 405 × 10
–6
C cm
–2
.

The catalytic activities for HCOO
–
oxidation were also evaluated by CV at a scan rate of 20 mV s
–1
in 1 M KOH containing 500 mM HCOOK.

For a single-cell operation, 1 mg
Pd
cm
–2
of PdB
Inc.
/C and Pd/C (20 wt %) catalysts were loaded on a carbon paper for anode GDL (AvCarb, MGL 190). Commercial Pt/C (1 mg
Pt
cm
–2
) (Tanaka Co., 46.7 wt %) was placed on the cathode GDL (Toray, TGPH-060). The catalyst slurry used in the hand spray method consisted of catalysts, DI water, 1-propanol (Junsei), and lab-made perfluorinated anion exchange ionomers (Dankook University). Both electrodes and an anion exchange membrane (Tokuyama A201) were combined by warm pressing at 60 °C for 5 min to prepare the membrane electrode assembly (MEA). The performance test of the MEA (size = 9.0 cm
2
) was carried out using a fuel cell station (Including Keysight N7950 A with N7909A as the electronic loads, Scitech Korea Co.) The cell temperature and relative humidity of the cathode were kept at 80 °C and 100%, respectively. The fuel (4 M KOH with 6 M HCOOK) and oxygen were supplied to the cell with a flow rate of 50 mL min
–1
and 500 sccm, respectively. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was performed with an amplitude of 2 mV at the applied potential of 0.85 V between 1 and 1000 Hz (Autolab electrochemical workstation, Metrohm, PGSTAT302N).

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
The morphological properties and crystallinity of PdB
Inc.
/C were intensively characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), and X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) (
Figure
1
). From the TEM images, PdB
Inc.
/C was observed to have well-dispersed spherical shape of Pd with an average particle size of around 3 nm, while larger Pd nanoparticles were observed in Pd/C, as shown in
Figure S1
.

div.p:
Figure 1. Various analysis of PdB
Inc.
/C (red) and Pd/C (black, used in a previous study
(24)
): (a) XRD pattern, (b) TEM image of PdB
Inc.
/C and its reduced fast Fourier transform (FFT), (c) X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectrum, and (d) X-ray near-edge structure (XANES) spectra (solid lines) with a Pd foil (dash-dotted line) and PdO (dotted line) samples.

div.div:
The reason why the PdB
Inc.
/C catalyst has a smaller particle size of Pd compared to Pd/C may be due to the better dispersion of B-doped Pd particles in the synthesis process, induced from the modification of metal–metal interaction. From the XRD pattern, PdB
Inc.
/C is negatively shifted compared to commercial Pd/C, pure Pd (JCPDS number: 461043), and previously used Pd/C
(24)
(
Figure
1
a). For Pd(111) measured as a dominant plane in XRD,
d
-spacing/lattice parameter of PdB
Inc.
/C was calculated to be 2.334/4.044 Å from 38.54°. The
d
-spacing/lattice parameter from fast Fourier transform (FFT) and the line profile of PdB
Inc.
/C in TEM was measured to be avg. 2.345/4.062 and 2.338/4.050 Å, which also correspond well with the XRD results (
Figures
1
b and
S2c
). For Pd/C, the
d
-spacing/lattice parameter was measured to be 2.331/4.037 Å from 38.6° in XRD, 2.334/4.044 Å in FFT, and 2.325/4.027 Å in the line profile (
Figures
1
a and
S2a,b
). Based on the above results, although the Pd lattice for both catalysts is expanded compared to the typical Pd lattice (3.89 Å from 40.1° for pure Pd), PdB
Inc.
/C shows a marginally expanded lattice structure caused by hydrogen or boron, compared to that of typical Pd.
(32,38)
The measured and calculated d-spacing and lattice parameters are listed in
Table S1
. The difference in the Pd–Pd radial distance of PdB
Inc.
/C (2.61 Å) in X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra also supports the marginal lattice expansion compared to Pd/C (2.58 Å) owing to the boron incorporated in the Pd lattice (
Figure
1
c). For these small difference, we could just infer that a slightly larger d-spacing and lattice constant might be from a bigger radius of B (87 pm) than that of H (53 pm) if these elements occupy same octahedral vacancies in Pd lattice. Based on the above results, the significant lattice expansion of PdB
Inc.
/C can be considered to be caused by the incorporated elements compared with typical Pd. However, in the X-ray near-edge structure (XANES) spectra from XAS, the two peaks of these Pd catalysts are negatively shifted compared to those of the Pd foil and PdO (
Figure
1
d). This is owing to the interaction between Pd and foreign elements such as hydrogen;
(32,39)
boron incorporation into the Pd lattice could possibly lead to the XANES peak shift and a balanced ratio between Pd
2+
and Pd
0
states; however, it is a little more biased to the presence of metallic states. Pd/C also shows a peak-shifted XANES spectrum due to the lattice change and due to the contribution of hydrogen toward developing the Pd
0
state.

For a comprehensive understanding of the oxidation states of PdB
Inc.
/C from XANES spectra and to identify the electronic interaction between Pd and B, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was conducted for both Pd catalysts (
Figure
2
).

div.p:
Figure 2. XPS analysis: (a) Pd 3d core level spectra and peak deconvolution for PdB
Inc.
/C and Pd/C,
(24)
(b) B 1s core level spectrum and peak deconvolution including fitted results (black) for raw data (gray), and (c) comparison of the valence band spectra. (i) PdB
Inc.
/C (solid line) and (ii) Pd/C (dotted line); each d-band width/d-band center was measured as (i) 4.11/2.81 eV and (ii) 3.82/2.51 eV, respectively.

div.div:
XPS spectra and deconvolution of Pd 3d show more accurate oxidation states for the surface of each catalyst (
Figure
2
a). From the core level, both catalysts show mixed states of Pd
0
(335.9 for PdB
Inc.
/C and 335.6 eV for Pd/C), Pd
2+
(336.7 for PdB
Inc.
/C and 337.1 eV for Pd/C), and Pd
4+
(338.0 eV for PdB
Inc.
/C). For all catalysts, the interval between split Pd 3d peaks (3d
5/2
and 3d
3/2
) is 5.3 eV. In the Pd 3d core level, PdB
Inc.
/C mainly shows the Pd
0
state; however, the oxidation states Pd
2+
and Pd
4+
are still observed. Furthermore, Pd 3d spectra of PdB
Inc.
/C are significantly blue-shifted from Pd. Considering that Pd/C positively shifts to 0.2–0.5 eV and shows a highly metallic state owing to hydrogen incorporation when compared with commercial Pd/C and a known Pd reference (e.g., Pd
0
335.1 eV),
(24,40)
incorporated B contributes more significantly and effectively to Pd core level shifts than hydrogen. Its relatively less metallic Pd state is also related to boron. Because both Pd and B are oxophilic, some oxidation states are observed. From the deconvolution of B 1s spectra for PdB
Inc.
/C, B–H (182.2 eV), B-I (188.9 eV), and B-II (191.1 eV) are observed (
Figure
2
b). All peak positions are in good agreement with B 1s observations for metal–boron interactions reported in other studies.
(23,27,41,42)
The B-I peak is specifically regarded as a result of metal–boron interactions.
(42)
Considering that the pure B 1s peak position is ∼191 eV, the B-I peak in PdB
Inc.
/C is negatively shifted. Pd 3d and B 1s peak positions are listed in
Tables S2 and S3
, respectively. In the point of chloride view in
Figure
2
b, we doubt that chloride could be affected by the electronic structure. If trace amount of Cl significantly affected the electronic structure of Pd, both Pd 3d in XPS and the work function of PdB
Inc.
/C could not be blue-shifted and alleviated and Cl peaks should be shifted in the opposite direction of Pd 3d. Furthermore, halides such as F easily accept electrons from metals.
(43)
If Cl chemically interacted with Pd, the work function should increase. However, Cl 2p shows a typical (sodium) chloride peak (198.2 eV) and organic Cl peak (∼200 eV). In addition, Pd B-I peak in B 1s indicates the metal–boron interaction.
(41,42)
Therefore, we conclude that Cl did not contribute to the electronic modification of Pd, and the modification is owed to boron. The effects of Cl, if any, are likely negligible. For the valence band (
Figure
2
c), PdB
Inc.
/C shows a broadened width (4.11 eV) and its d-band center (2.81 eV) is shifted away from the Fermi level (
E
F
), compared to those of Pd/C (3.82 and 2.51 eV, respectively). Many studies have investigated the controversial issue of the electronic structure of metal–metal and metal–adatom catalysts.
(7,9,10,12,16,17,22,23,27,29,30,33,34,41−46)
Based on some of these studies that were relevant to palladium–boron interaction,
(22,23,27,33,41,43)
it is reasoned that the downshift of the d-band center and the core level, as well as d-band broadening, was owing to a sufficient overlap between metal d- and boron p-orbitals.
(22,43)
The direction of electron transfer from the incorporated boron to palladium was also considered. Even though its core level was positively shifted,
(24)
Pd/C showed a narrow d-band width and upshifted d-band center. This contradictory result could be explained by the influence of lattice expansion on the electronic structure. According to Gelatt et al., the d-band width decreases owing to the lattice expansion caused by the insertion of interstitial adatoms, such as Li, which leads to the net charge transfer from Pd to Li, even though Li donates electrons to Pd.
(43)
Likewise, hydrogen incorporation affects the decrease in the Pd d-band width, which means that the electron transfer from H to Pd observed in the core level is not enough to compensate for the influence of lattice expansion on the electronic structure. In other words, the electronic modification of Pd by the incorporated H cannot overcome the lattice expansion. On the other hand, the electronic modification of Pd by the incorporated B overcomes the lattice expansion, even some of oxidized states in the core level, and therefore, the d-band width increase/d-band center downshift and blue shift of the Pd 3d core level are observed. In other literature for the alloy catalyst, it was reported that the downshift of the d-band center and the metal core level results in weakening chemisorption strength between the catalyst and adsorbate so that the catalytic activity could be increased.
(12,46)
These studies are consistent with our observations and support our interpretation of XPS. The work function (WF) results obtained from UPS analysis are 4.46 eV for PdB
Inc.
/C and 4.98 eV for Pd/C (
Figure
3
).

div.p:
Figure 3. UPS profiles for PdB
Inc.
/C (solid line) and Pd/C (dotted line).

div.div:
Compared to the WF of polycrystalline Pd (∼4.8–4.99 eV),
(47)
PdB
Inc.
/C shows a significantly reduced WF, whereas Pd/C has a relatively higher value. Because WF is directly related to
E
F
, this reasoning can support the conclusions made earlier (d-band broadening and downshift of the d-band center were owing to the uplift of
E
F
and orbital overlapping, which were caused by the boron incorporation.)

Electrochemical analysis was also conducted on the PdB
Inc.
/C catalyst as the working electrode in CV and the anode electrode in single-cell operation (
Figures
4
and
5
).

div.p:
Figure 4. Electrochemical analysis of (i) Pd/C, (ii) PdB
Inc.
/C, and (iii) commercial Pd/C. (a) CV in 1 M KOH, (b) CV in 1 M KOH containing 500 mM HCOOK. (c) EIS curves of Pd/C and PdB
Inc.
/C electrodes in N
2
-saturated 1 M KOH and 0.5 M HCOOK electrolyte at 0.6 V vs Hg/HgO (an equivalent circuit for the EIS spectra is also shown). (i) and (iii) are from our previous study.
(24)

Figure 5. (a)
I–V
polarization curves of (i) Pd/C anode catalyst and (ii) and (iii) PdB
Inc.
/C anode catalyst (fuel flow rate of 10 mL min
–1
for (i) and (ii) and 50 mL min
–1
for (iii)). Loading amount of each catalyst = 1 mg
Pd
cm
–2
. Cell temperature = 80 °C. The fuel contained 6.0 M HCOOK with 4.0 M KOH. The oxygen flow rate on cathode = 500 sccm with 100% RH.
I–V
curves were measured for 10 s at each current point, with an increment of 0.2 A for (i) and (ii), and 0.5 A for (iii). In the current–voltage measurement, the open-circuit duration for refueling was at least 60 s. Insets show images of contact angle measurement on Pd/C and PdB
Inc.
/C electrodes. (b) Bode plot based on EIS data of the single cell with Pd/C and PdB
Inc.
/C anode electrodes measured at 0.85 V (marked with a blue arrow in (a)). Insets show Nyquist plots of both catalysts used.

div.div:
Figure
4
a shows CV profiles for PdB
Inc.
/C and Pd/C
(24)
in a 1 M KOH electrolyte as a base CV. From the base CV, the peak potential of desorption of
H
ads
is measured to be 349.6 mV for PdB
Inc.
/C and 361.4 mV for Pd/C. The chemisorption strength of
H
ads
on PdB
Inc.
/C is weakened by the modified electronic structure of Pd owing to the incorporated boron. From the backward peak of reduction of Pd–O from ∼1.0–0.5 V, the electrochemical surface area (ECSA) is calculated to be 41.59 and 38.15 m
2
g
–1
for PdB
Inc.
/C and Pd/C, respectively. The particle-size distribution of Pd may contribute to the increased ECSA of PdB
Inc.
/C.
(15,48)
The catalytic activity of PdB
Inc.
/C for the oxidation of HCOO
–
was measured using CV in 1 M KOH containing 500 mM HCOOK, as shown in
Figure
4
b (a comparison with CV of Pd/C is also made). The onset potential of HCOO
–
oxidation was determined as the oxidation potential right after the desorption peak of absorbed hydrogen. PdB
Inc.
/C (149 mV) shows a much faster onset and catalytic activity for the oxidation of HCOO
–
than Pd/C (164 mV). From CV, the obtained peak current densities are 91.47 and 72.46 mA cm
–2
, respectively. Furthermore, current density, mass activities, and ECSA-normalized current densities at 0.6 V vs RHE are calculated to be 74.1 mA cm
–2
, 1780 A mg
Pd
–1
, and 2850 A m
Pd
–2
for PdB
Inc.
/C, respectively; corresponding values for Pd/C are 59.7 mA cm
–2
, 1430 A mg
Pd
–1
, and 2500 A m
Pd
–2
, respectively (
Table S4
). The Tafel slopes for each catalyst in
Figure
4
b were calculated, and the slope of PdB
Inc.
/C (102 mV dec
–1
) was smaller than that of Pd/C (115 mV dec
–1
). For commercial Pd/C, the peak current density and tafel slope are 49.37 mA cm
–2
and 122 mV dec
–1
, even though its ECSA is larger than others (62.38 m
2
g
–1
). Considering that the desorption of H
ads
originated by HCOO
–
, which produces one electron, is regarded as the rate-determining step,
(4,6,24)
the decreased Tafel slope (<120 mV dec
–1
) is directly connected to the improvement of reaction kinetics. Both Pd catalysts show faster kinetics in the experimental results; however, the number of electrons available for the oxidation reaction on PdB
Inc.
/C is higher compared to that on Pd/C. The onset potential of PdB
Inc.
/C is faster than that of Pd/C, which confirms the faster reaction kinetics of PdB
Inc.
/C. Therefore, the incorporation of B into Pd significantly contributes to the weakening of the adsorption strength of H
ads
, and this modification improves the catalytic activity for oxidation of HCOO
–
. The improved reaction kinetics on the surface of PdB
Inc.
/C was also confirmed by EIS analysis (
Figure
4
c), which shows a noticeably decreased charge-transfer resistance (137 Ω cm
–2
) in comparison with that of Pd/C (213 Ω cm
–2
). The stability of PdB
Inc.
/C is also evaluated by the cycling method and compared with the stability of commercial Pd/C (
Figure S3
). The forward peak current density of commercial Pd/C sees an obvious decrease after 200 cycles of CVs, which is nearly 80% of the initial cycle. On the other hand, PdB
Inc.
/C possesses stable electrochemical activity for formate oxidation, showing a similar level of current densities even after 200 cycles of the stability test.

As a final criterion for ascertaining the oxidation of HCOO
–
, single-cell evaluation for the configured MEA with PdB
Inc.
/C as the anode catalyst is carried out and compared with the evaluation with Pd/C (
Figure
5
).

In
Figure
5
a showing the polarization curves with a low fuel flow rate, the peak power densities of Pd/C and PdB
Inc.
/C are measured to be 155.4 and 223.5 mW cm
–2
, respectively. PdB
Inc.
/C has a lower activation and Ohmic loss, which is because the high degree of electronic modification leads to a better catalytic activity. In particular, the enhanced fuel cell performance became more obvious in the Ohmic loss region (<∼0.85 V), which indicates the contribution of the improved electron transfer due to the incorporation of B. Furthermore, PdB
Inc.
/C shows a better concentration loss compared to Pd/C. In a direct formate fuel cell system, fuel accessibility for the electrode is critical to alleviating the mass-transport limitation.
(49)
If the metallic states on the anode electrode are too high, such as that in Pd/C,
(24)
fuel accessibility might be hindered, even though its catalytic activity is improved. However, the lower metallic state of PdB
Inc.
/C, caused by B, could facilitate the fuel accessibility so that the concentration loss is alleviated. Additionally, the contact angle measurements shown in the inset images in
Figure
5
prove that PdB
Inc.
/C exhibits higher hydrophilicity (87°) in comparison with that exhibited by Pd/C (135°), which confirms the higher affinity of fuel toward the electrode surface. With a higher fuel flow rate ((c) in
Figure
5
), PdB
Inc.
/C anode shows an outstanding performance measured at 401.8 mW cm
–2
. Compared to 276.2 mW cm
–2
with a Pd/C anode in a previous study,
(24)
it is again clear that the incorporated boron contributes toward not only the improvement of the oxidation activity of HCOO
–
but also the alleviation of mass-transport limitation in a practical system. With the same MEA components, a single-cell durability test was also carried out at 100 mA cm
–2
for 18 h (
Figure S4
). The cell voltage was first decreased from ∼0.79 to ∼0.6 V at the 2 h-point of the cell operation. However, the cell voltage after 2 h seemed stable, showing 0.6 V until the end of the test. According to the stability test results, PdB
Inc.
/C shows higher stability in comparison with that exhibited by Pd/C, and therefore, the results of the single-cell durability test were in good agreement with the half-cell electrochemical test.

Figure
5
b shows bode plots of EIS observations, compensated electrode resistance to compare anode catalyst effects accurately. There is a significant resistance difference in the anode region (compare
R
ct,Pd/C
and
R
ct,PdB/C
), suggesting an increase in conductivity due to the electronic modification. It is further confirmed that PdB
Inc.
/C shows decreased charge-transfer resistance compared to Pd/C (
Figure
4
c). Considering that fuel cell performance was limited by various transfer-controlled reactions at the given potential, the reasons for improved cell performance of PdB
Inc.
/C need to be supposed not only for electrocatalytic activity but also the electrode factor of wettability.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
A B-incorporated Pd electrocatalyst (PdB
Inc.
/C) was synthesized and various physicochemical analyses were conducted. The particle-size distribution was substantially uniform in PdB
Inc.
/C. This catalyst also showed a slightly lattice-expanded structure and fewer oxidized and metallic states because its electronic structure was modified by incorporation of B in the Pd lattice. In XPS profiles, the Pd 3d core level and the valence band (specifically the d-band center) were positively shifted. The d-band width was also broadened. This electronic structure modification was because of the orbital overlap between Pd and B, which caused the upshift of the reference level. The reduced WF of PdB
Inc.
/C could be regarded as evidence for the upshift of the Fermi level. The direction of electron transfer is from B to Pd based on these experimental observations. The modification resulted in significant weakening adsorption strength of adsorbed hydrogen in spite of disadvantages such as lattice expansion and little oxidized state, and therefore, the catalytic activity and performance of PdB
Inc.
/C for the oxidation of HCOO
–
was significantly enhanced. Furthermore, the relatively fewer metallic states in PdB
Inc.
/C, caused by B, have the advantage of facilitating fuel accessibility from the point of view of the anode electrode in a practical system. Consequently, the maximum power density of PdB
Inc.
/C was 401.8 mW cm
–2
. This investigation offers an extensive understanding of the electronic effect in such catalysts and excludes other complicated factors that affect catalytic activity such as the ensemble effect in Pd–admetal alloys, which have a great OH affinity or an ambiguous direction of electron transfer through many orbital overlaps.

Decarolis, Donato; Lezcano-Gonzalez, Ines; Gianolio, Diego; Beale, Andrew M.

Pd nanoparticles supported on SiO2, Si3N4 and Al2O3 were studied to examine the effect of particle size and support type on the hydrogenation of 1,3-butadiene. Pd nanoparticles were produced using a reverse micelle method resulting in particles with a remarkably small particle size distribution (σ < < 1 nm). The support type and particle size were obsd. to affect both catalytic activity and product selectivity. All catalysts showed a decrease of their activity with time on stream, paired with an increase in selectivity to butenes (1-butene and cis/trans-2-butene) from a product stream initially dominated by n-butane. In situ XAFS demonstrated a correlation between the formation of palladium hydride and n-butane prodn. in the early stages (∼ 1 h) of reaction. The extent of palladium hydride formation, as well as its depletion with time on stream, was dependent on both particle size and support type. Metallic Pd was identified as the species selective towards the prodn. of butenes.

A review. Direct formate fuel cells (DFFC), which convert the chem. energy stored in formate directly into electricity, are recently attracting more attention, primarily because of the use of the carbon-neutral fuel and the low-cost electrocatalytic and membrane materials. As an emerging energy technol., the DFFC has made a rapid progress in recent years (currently, the state-of-the-art power d. is 591 mW cm-2 at 60 °C). This article provides a review of past research on the development of this type of fuel cell, including the working principle, mechanisms and materials of the electrocatalytic oxidn. of formate, singe-cell designs and performance, as well as innovative system designs. In addn., future perspectives with regard to the development of this fuel cell system are also highlighted.

A direct formate fuel cell (DFFC) operated with a fuel of alk. potassium formate has been studied using Pd anode and Ag cathode electrocatalysts in an intermediate temp. range of 80 to 120 °C by means of cyclic voltammetry and single cell measurements. Voltammetric studies clearly show that the kinetics of the formate electrooxidn. on Pd in alk. media is substantially increased with increasing temp., leading to a high apparent activation energy of around 74.3 ± 6.2 kJ mol- 1. Preliminary single cell measurements show that increasing operating temp. and the formate concn. obviously increase the performance. A DFFC operated with 6 mol dm- 3 HCOOK and at 120 °C demonstrates a peak power d. of around 160 mW cm- 2 over a c.d. range of 250 to 550 mA cm- 2 without Ohmic resistance correction. The DFFC is therefore a promising high performance, environmentally benign and low cost fuel cell technol.

Anodic and catalytic oxidns. of formate ion at an active Pd electrode were studied by the potential-sweep and the galvanostatic methods in connection with the measurements of the rate of formation of H on Pd during the catalytic decompn. of formate. A Pd surface oxidized by pre-anodization is reduced with ease by dissolved formate. Formate adsorbed on the cleaned surface decomp. into 2 fragments such as Had and CO-2ad through the reaction HCO2- → Had + CO-2ad. On standing, CO-2ad is oxidized further by OH- to CO32- and Had. In the absence of polarization, the net reaction of the catalytic decompn. is HCO2- + OH- → CO32- + 2Had. Presence of Had on Pd hinders this reaction to some extent, but H evolution was observed at high electrolyte concns. The net reaction of anodic oxidn. of formate is HCO2- + 3OH- → CO32- + 2H2O + 2 e, in which reactions such as Had + OH- → H2O + e and CO-2ad + 2 OH- → CO32- + H2O + e are involved. The nature of the open-circuit voltage in this system is examd. by taking these species into consideration.

The mechanistic origin is investigated of oxidn. of HCOO- on Pd/C in alk. media using H/D kinetic isotope effect studies and electrochem. expts., such as cyclic voltammetry, step-linear sweep voltammetry, and stripping voltammetry. It is reveal that HCOO- is oxidized to CO2 through a direct pathway, and the oxidn. of Hads is the rate detg. step. The slow oxidn. kinetics of Hads, which causes a site-occupying effect, suppress the oxidn. of HCOO-, and a more distinct phenomenon is obsd. in the potential region for Hads. Bollmann, Luis; Ratts, Joshua L.; Joshi, Ajay M.; Williams, W. Damion; Pazmino, Jorge; Joshi, Yogesh V.; Miller, Jeffrey T.; Kropf, A. Jeremy; Delgass, W. Nicholas; Ribeiro, Fabio H.

The effect of Zn addn. on the Pd turnover rate (TOR) for the H2O-gas shift (WGS) reaction was studied for 2% Pd on alumina with Zn content varying from 0 to 19% Zn by wt. Over 85% of the Zn reacted with alumina to form Zn aluminate with a fraction reacting with Pd. The av. Pd-Zn coordination no. as measured by EXAFS increased monotonically from 0 to 4.5 as the Zn loading on alumina increased. At a loading of 2% Pd and 19% Zn on alumina the molar fraction of Zn in the Pd particles was 0.34, and the turnover rate increased by a factor of 13, as compared with the pure metallic Pd supported on alumina, to 3.6 × 10-2 mol H2 s-1 (mol exposed Pd)-1 at 280°, 6.8% CO, 8.5% CO2, 21.9% H2O and 37.4% H2 at 1 atm. The formation of the ordered 1:1 PdZn intermetallic compd. by deposition of Pd on Zn oxide increased the av. Pd-Zn coordination no. to 5.9 and the WGS turnover rate by a factor of 20 to 5.3 × 10-2 mol H2 s-1 (mol exposed Pd)-1. The bonding of adsorbed CO changed from 80% bridging on pure Pd to 90% linear on the 1:1 PdZn intermetallic compd. as detd. by diffuse reflectance IR spectroscopy performed under WGS conditions. The fraction of CO binding linearly to Pd correlated linearly with the WGS rate per Pd on the surface. Because the dispersion of the samples was about the same, this result implies that the no. of active sites can be counted by the fraction of CO binding linearly. A simple random substitution model for PdZn distribution was used to est. the concn. of Pd and Zn on the surface, based on the coordination nos. measured by EXAFS. The correlation of the reaction rate with the types of sites on catalysts with 6 different Pd-Zn compns. shows that the data is consistent with an active site composed of surface Pd atoms with surface coordination to 2 Pd and 4 Zn atoms, which is the coordination expected for the (111) plane of the 1:1 PdZn intermetallic compd. An alternate explanation for the promotional effect of Zn on Pd/alumina is that the formation of Zn aluminate inhibits the deleterious Pd-alumina interaction.

Pd-Au bimetallic catalysts: understanding alloy effects from planar models and (supported) nanoparticles
Gao, Feng; Goodman, D. Wayne
Chemical Society Reviews
(
2012
),
41
(
24
),
8009-8020
CODEN:
CSRVBR
; ISSN:
0306-0012
.
(
Royal Society of Chemistry
)
A review. Pd-Au bimetallic catalysts often display enhanced catalytic activities and selectivities compared with Pd-alone catalysts. This enhancement is often caused by two alloy effects, i.e., ensemble and ligand effects. The ensemble effect is a diln. of surface Pd by Au. With increasing surface Au coverage, contiguous Pd ensembles disappear and isolated Pd ensembles form. For certain reactions, for example vinyl acetate synthesis, this effect is responsible for reaction rate enhancement via the formation of highly active surface sites, e.g., isolated Pd pairs. The disappearance of contiguous Pd ensembles also switches off side reactions catalyzed by these sites. This explains the selectivity increase of certain reactions, for example direct H2O2 synthesis. The ligand effects are electronic perturbation of Pd by Au. Via direct charge transfer or by affecting bond lengths, the ligand effects cause the Pd d band to be more filled, moving the d-band center away from the Fermi level. Both changes make Pd more "at. like" therefore binding reactants and products more weakly. For certain reactions, this eliminates a so-called "self-poisoning" effect and enhances activity/selectivity.

CO tolerance of pure Pt, Pt-Co, and Pt-Ru alloys was studied by XPS combined with an electrochem. cell (EC-XPS) to design better anode catalysts. After electrochem. stabilization and/or CO adsorption the electrodes were transferred to the XPS chamber without exposure to air to avoid contamination of the surfaces. Alloying with Co or Ru modified the electronic structure of Pt atoms resulting in a pos. core level (CL) shift of Pt 4f7/2 which can weaken the Pt-CO interaction. For the Pt-Co alloy electrode the Pt 4f7/2 CL shift remained after electrochem. stabilization despite Co dissoln. and formation of a Pt layer. Changes in surface core level shifts (ΔSCLSs) induced by CO adsorption were evaluated and related to the CO adsorption energy. The values of ΔSCLS at these alloys were smaller than that of pure Pt, indicating that Ru and Co are effective elements to weaken the bond strength of Pt-CO.

Pd-Cu/C and Pd/C catalysts were synthesized via a metal salt redn. method. Phys., chem., and electrochem. characterizations of these two catalysts were compared and used to understand the impact of copper on the palladium surface during the electrochem. oxidn. of formate and ethanol in alk. media. Cyclic voltammetry and chronoamperometry display an enhanced oxidn. rate and stability for Pd-Cu/C alloy catalyst toward formate and ethanol in alk. media when compared to Pd/C catalyst. The authors demonstrate herein two important features of a Pd87Cu13/C electrocatalyst that indicate it is a more efficient catalyst in alk. media than Pd/C for the electrochem. oxidn. of three polyalcs.: ethylene glycol, propylene glycol, and glycerol. First, the authors discovered more efficient behavior in a three electrode electrochem. cell, where the electrochem. oxidn. rate of ethylene glycol and propylene glycol was 4 times faster on Pd87Cu13/C than Pd/C. In glycerol, the oxidn. rate was 3 times faster in the electrochem. cell. This increase in oxidn. rate is due to a combination of the electronic and bifunctional effects. Second, the Pd87Cu13/C catalyst is also more efficient than Pd/C in an operating alk. direct liq. fuel cell, although the efficiency gains are smaller than the electrochem. cell. During fuel cell testing, the max. power d. of a propylene glycol fuel cell was 86% greater when the anode catalyst was Pd-Cu/C compared with Pd/C. The max. power densities of the glycerol and ethylene glycol fuel cells increased by 75% and 32%, resp. These polyalc. mols. are of significant interest because they can be made from renewable sources and used to produce power in alk. direct liq. fuel cells.

Formate is the one legitimate carbon-neutral fuel that has the capability of being considered an alternative to alc. fuels amidst the growing demand for efficient fuel-cell systems. In this manuscript, it is demonstrated, for the first time, a class of binary Pd-Ni alloy nanoparticles over two different carbon supports showing exceptional enhancement of the formate oxidn. reaction (FOR) performance in alk. medium, compared to Pd/C. The synergistic effects of Pd and oxophilic Ni along with the electronic structure alteration of Pd induced through alloying resulted in an effective change in its catalytic ability, leading to a 5-time enhancement in the overall c.d. along with a lower overpotential during formate oxidn. compared to Pd/C. The more active Pd catalytic sites of the nanoalloy helped to yield mass activities as high as 4.5 A mg-1Pd and 7.8 A mg-1Pd during FOR. The structural and electrochem. anal. justifies the synergistic effects and alterations in the Pd lattice ensuing a superior enhancement of electrochem. active Pd sites.

In this paper, we report the prepn. of a highly active and durable ordered intermetallic PdFe catalyst supported on carbon black for formic acid oxidn. reaction (FAOR) by high-temp. heat treatment under a reductive atm. We found that the ordered intermetallic PdFe catalyst exhibited considerably better catalytic activity and durability toward FAOR than the disordered PdFe and pure Pd catalysts because of the high alloying degree between Pd and Fe, which induced a downshift of the Pd d-band center and structural modifications that formed a superlattice cryst. structure with Pd surface segregation. We analyzed the improved catalytic properties of the ordered intermetallic PdFe catalyst through various electrochem. analyses such as cyclic voltammetry, CO oxidn. methods, chronoamperometry, physicochem. analyses such as XPS, and synchrotron radiation methods such as X-ray absorption spectroscopy. D. functional theory calcn. verified the improved FAOR activity of the ordered intermetallic PdFe catalyst. In addn., a single cell based on the ordered intermetallic PdFe catalyst was also fabricated and exhibited enhanced cell performance compared to those based on the other catalysts. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study on the prepn. of an ordered intermetallic PdFe catalyst for FAOR with real single-cell application in direct formic acid fuel cells (DFAFCs). We believe that our results will be helpful for the development of highly active and durable Pd alloy catalysts for FAOR and the commercialization of DFAFC.

Promoting the formate oxidn. reaction (FOR) is central to develop promising direct formate fuel cells, but current electrocatalysts are suffering from low activity and ultrapoor stability. Herein, the ternary PdAgRh nanoalloys with ultrathin two-dimensional architecture are for the 1st time synthesized and employed as a novel class of electrocatalysts for the FOR. Benefitting from unique nanostructure as well as oxophilic Rh surface oxides, the Pd55Ag30Rh15/C electrocatalyst demonstrates an exceptional FOR activity of 1.85 A mgPd-1, showing a 4.74-fold improvement compared to the com. Pd/C, and retains the c.d. of 150 mA mgPd-1 after a long-term test, representing the greatest durability among all available FOR electrocatalysts. More strikingly, extending the upper limit potential (ULP) of cyclic voltammetry is revealed to facilitate the surface reconstruction of the Pd55Ag30Rh15/C electrocatalyst to in situ form Ag surface oxides (Ag-O), resulting in a highly active and stable Pd/Ag-O interface at the at. scale, which considerably boost the FOR performance. In particular, the reconstructed Pd55Ag30Rh15/C electrocatalyst exhibits a mass activity of 3.26 A mgPd-1 with 74.2% of initial activity retained after 1000 cycles. This work showcases an effective strategy to tune surface reconstruction on multimetallic nanoalloys for robust FOR electrocatalysts and beyond.

Alloying palladium (Pd) catalysts with various metalloid and nonmetal elements can improve their catalytic performance in different chem. reactions. However, current nanosynthesis methods can only generate Pd alloys contg. one metalloid or nonmetal, which limits the types of element combinations that may be used to improve Pd-based nanocatalysts. Herein, we report a simple soft-templating synthetic strategy to co-alloy Pd with the metalloid boron (B) and the nonmetal phosphorus (P) to generate ternary PdBP mesoporous nanospheres (MSs) with three-dimensional dendritic frameworks. We use a one-step aq. synthesis method where dimethylamine borane and sodium hypophosphite serve as the B and P sources, resp., as well as the co-reducing agents to drive the nucleation and growth of ternary PdBP alloy on a sacrificial dioctadecyldimethylammonium chloride template. The concn. of metalloid to nonmetal and the diams. of dendritic MSs can be tailored. The synthetic protocol is also extended to other multicomponent PdMBP alloy MSs to generate different types of dendritic mesoporous frameworks. Boron and phosphorus are known to accelerate the kinetics of the electrochem. oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) and alc. oxidn. reactions (AORs), because their alloys promote the decompn. of oxygen-contg. intermediates on Pd surfaces. The dendritic mesoporous morphol. of the ternary PdBP MSs also accelerates electron/mass transfer and exposes numerous active sites, enabling better performance in the ORR and AORs. Extending the surfactant-templating synthetic route to multiple types of elements will enable the generation of libraries of multicomponent metal-metalloid-nonmetal alloy nanostructures with functions that are suitable for various targeted applications.

Direct formate fuel cells are promising future power sources due to their environmental friendliness and cost effectiveness. However, their further development and application are hindered by the lack of high-activity catalysts for the formate oxidn. reaction (FOR). For the first time, alloying Pd and Ce in inverse CeO2/Pd nanoparticles is obsd. and confirmed here by a shift of the diffraction peak, an increase of the lattice spacing and a downward shift of the d-band center. The as-synthesized Pd72Ce28/C catalyst exhibits a mass specific activity of 1.1 A mgPd-1, which is 3.8 times higher than that of the com. A neg. alloy formation energy of -10.44 eV in the Pd3Ce1 alloy is obsd. from d. functional theory calcns., where the effect of alloying Pd and Ce on the FOR catalytic activity can be attributed to the weakened hydrogen binding energy of -1.04 eV and reduced potential limiting barrier of 0.23 eV on the Pd3Ce1 (111) surface. This systematic work, from facile synthesis to theor. simulations, not only highlights the crit. role of the synergy of the electronic effect and oxophilic effect in enhancing the catalytic activity, but also promotes further research on the mechanism of the FOR in alk. media.

Lindlar catalysts comprising of palladium/calcium carbonate modified with lead acetate and quinoline are widely employed industrially for the partial hydrogenation of alkynes. However, their use is restricted, particularly for food, cosmetic and drug manuf., due to the extremely toxic nature of lead, and the risk of its leaching from catalyst surface. In addn., the catalysts also exhibit poor selectivities in a no. of cases. Here we report that a non-surface modification of palladium gives rise to the formation of an ultra-selective nanocatalyst. Boron atoms are found to take residence in palladium interstitial lattice sites with good chem. and thermal stability. This is favored due to a strong host-guest electronic interaction when supported palladium nanoparticles are treated with a borane THF soln. The adsorptive properties of palladium are modified by the subsurface boron atoms and display ultra-selectivity in a no. of challenging alkyne hydrogenation reactions, which outclass the performance of Lindlar catalysts.

Direct formic acid fuel cell (DFAFC) with Pd-based catalyst anode is a promising energy converter to power portable devices. However, its commercialization is entangled with insufficient activity and poor stability of existing anode catalysts. Here we initially report that a DFAFC using facilely synthesized Pd-B/C with ca. 6 at. % B doping as the anode catalyst yields a max. output power d. of 316 mW cm-2 at 30 °C, twice that with a same DFAFC using otherwise the state-of-the-art Pd/C. More strikingly, at a const. voltage of 0.3 V, the output power of the former cell is ca. 9 times as high as that of the latter after 4.5 h of continuous operation. In situ attenuated total reflection IR spectroscopy is applied to probe comparatively the interfacial behaviors at Pd-B/C and Pd/C in conditions mimicking those for the DFAFC anode operation, revealing that the significantly improved cell performance correlates well with a substantially lowered CO accumulation at B-doped Pd surfaces.

Boron doping can boost the catalytic activity of palladium for diverse reactions. Precise control of the doping content is crucial but remains difficult in current synthesis, which generally involves the use of instable and costly borane-org. compds. Herein, by taking advantage of the relatively strong solvation of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) to Na+ and the increased stability BH4- in DMF, we synthesize B-Pd interstitial nanocrystals in DMF, with NaBH4 acting as a reductant and boron source. The boron content, which can be readily tuned by changing the reaction time and NaBH4 concn., can reach up to 20 at.%. Such a high boron doping results in a great beneficial effect on the catalytic capability of Pd toward the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR). The synthesized B-Pd nanoalloy exhibits a mass and specific activity for ORR that are, resp., ca. 14 and 14.6 times higher than those of the state-of-the-art com. Pt catalyst in alk. soln. D. functional theory (DFT) calcns. reveal three types of surface sites that are responsible for the enhanced activity, namely, Pd-BO2 assemblies, Pd atoms neighbored by the assemblies, and the Pd atoms modified with subsurface B atoms. The Pd-BO2 assembly has a Pt-like activity, while the neighboring Pd-BO2 assembly and subsurface B-modified Pd atoms could catalyze ORR much more efficiently than Pt. The facile and controllable boron doping in palladium should strengthen the power of Pd-based catalysts and, therefore, provides great prospects for their widespread application.

A highly active alternative to Pt electrocatalysts for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), which is the cathode-electrode reaction of fuel cells, is sought for higher fuel-cell performance. Our theoretical modelling reveals that B-doped Pd (Pd-B) weakens the absorption of ORR intermediates with nearly optimal binding energy by lowering the barrier associated with O2 dissociation, suggesting Pd-B should be highly active for ORR. In fact, Pd-B, facile synthesized by an electroless deposition process, exhibits 2.2 times and 8.8 times higher specific activity and 14 times and 35 times less costly than commercial pure Pd and Pt catalysts, respectively. Another computational result is that the surface core level of Pd is negatively shifted by B doping, as confirmed by XPS, and implies that filling the density of states related to the anti-bonding of oxygen to Pd surfaces with excess electrons from B doping, weakens the O bonding to Pd and boosts the catalytic activity.

Noble-metal-metalloid binary palladium-boron (Pd-B) nanoalloys are interesting because the smaller boron atoms enlarge the Pd-Pd interlattice spacings and modify the binding energy barriers of catalytic intermediates. Binary Pd-B nanoalloys with nanostructured morphologies are an emerging class of (electro)catalysts that leverage these properties to enhance their performance in various chem. reactions. We describe here the first synthesis of Pd-B alloy mesoporous nanospheres (MNSs) and evaluate their electrocatalytic performance in the ethanol oxidn. reaction (EOR). This method uses dimethylamine borane and boric acid as both the reducing agents and boron sources and amphiphilic dioctadecyldimethylammonium chloride (DODAC) as the surfactant template. The cylindrical mesophase of DODAC inhibits the mobility of the Pd metal precursor and confines the cryst. growth to form binary Pd-B MNSs with three-dimensional dendritic center-radial mesochannels. We demonstrate that the synthetic protocol can be adopted to rationally tune the diams. of the Pd-B MNSs from 30 nm to 120 nm without destroying the mesoporous structure and elemental compn. The Pd-B MNSs combine high surface area with favorable electrocatalytic surface properties to generate exceptional electrocatalytic performance for the EOR under alk. conditions, illustrating the potential of this method as a platform to yield a new type of highly efficient electrocatalyst.

Electroless nickel coating process has experienced remarkable modifications since its invention by Branner and Riddell in 1946. This process has proven to be very useful for applying uniform, hard, wear resistant coatings on many kinds of substrates including metals, alloys and even non-metallic materials such as plastics. Ni-B coatings have high hardness (higher than tool steels) and high wear resistance (better than hard chromium coatings) but inferior corrosion resistant properties (Ni-P coatings).The successful development of Ni-P composite coatings through electroless coating process and attractive properties of Ni-B coatings have remarkably motivated the research community to develop cost effective and high performance Ni-B coatings to fulfill the challenging requirements of chem., oil, automobile, petrochem., electronic, aerospace and textile industries. Since reasonable advancements have been made in the field of electroless Ni-B coatings, it warrants, reviewing their development, physicochem. properties, and deposition mechanism to have deep insight of the earlier work and to design new processing techniques to cope up their existed limitations. In this article, a comprehensive review on electroless Ni-B coatings has been under taken with an emphasize on the coating bath compns. (nickel source, reducing agent, complexing agent, bath stabilizers etc),characterization techniques (structural, chem. and mech.), factors affecting deposit properties and post coating treatments (heat treatment etc). Finally, some examples of the industrial applications of Ni-B coatings have also been discussed to have an idea about the diversity of their utility.

Binary and ternary composite films of Pd, multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) and Ni have been obtained on glassy carbon electrodes and investigated for electrocatalysis of methanol oxidn. in 1 M KOH. It is obsd. that small addn. (1-5%) of MWCNTs to Pd increases the apparent electrocatalytic activity of the electrode considerably, the magnitude of enhancement, however, being the greatest (5-8 times) with 1% MWCNT. 1% Ni introduction to the active Pd-1% MWCNT electrode increased the apparent electrocatalytic activity by 1.4-1.7 times further. Among the electrodes investigated, the Pd-1% MWCNT-1% Ni composite electrode has the greatest apparent electrocatalytic activity. The enhanced electrocatalytic activity of the electrodes is ascribed to their improved geometrical as well as electronic properties.

Interstitial Boron Atoms in the Palladium Lattice of an Industrial Type of Nanocatalyst: Properties and Structural Modifications
Chen, Tianyi; Ellis, Ieuan; Hooper, Thomas J. N.; Liberti, Emanuela; Ye, Lin; Lo, Benedict T. W.; O'Leary, Colum; Sheader, Alexandra A.; Martinez, Gerardo T.; Jones, Lewys; Ho, Ping-Luen; Zhao, Pu; Cookson, James; Bishop, Peter T.; Chater, Philip; Hanna, John V.; Nellist, Peter; Tsang, Shik Chi Edman

It is well-established that the inclusion of small at. species such as boron (B) in powder metal catalysts can subtly modify catalytic properties, and the assocd. changes in the metal lattice imply that the B atoms are located in the interstitial sites. However, there is no compelling evidence for the occurrence of interstitial B atoms, and there is a concomitant lack of detailed structural information describing the nature of this occupancy and its effects on the metal host. In this work, we use an innovative combination of high-resoln. 11B magic-angle-spinning (MAS) and 105Pd static solid-state NMR , synchrotron X-ray diffraction (SXRD), in situ X-ray pair distribution function (XPDF), scanning transmission electron microscopy-annular dark field imaging (STEM-ADF), electron ptychog., and electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) to investigate the B atom positions, properties, and structural modifications to the palladium lattice of an industrial type interstitial boron doped palladium nanoparticle catalyst system (Pd-intB/C NPs). In this study, we report that upon B incorporation into the Pd lattice, the overall fcc. (FCC) lattice is maintained; however, short-range disorder is introduced. The 105Pd static solid-state NMR illustrates how different types (and levels) of structural strain and disorder are introduced in the nanoparticle history. These structural distortions can lead to the appearance of small amts. of local hcp. (HCP) structured material in localized regions. The short-range lattice tailoring of the Pd framework to accommodate interstitial B dopants in the octahedral sites of the distorted FCC structure can be imaged by electron ptychog. This study describes new toolsets that enable the characterization of industrial metal nanocatalysts across length scales from macro- to microanal., which gives important guidance to the structure-activity relationship of the system.

Bimetallic alloy surfaces exhibit quite different adsorption properties from properties of the elemental metal surfaces. The differences in the behavior can be explained in terms of electronic (ligand effects) and structural (ensemble compn. effects) concepts. Auger electron spectroscopy-thermal desorption spectroscopy measurements were used to characterize the surface of 2 polycryst. Co50Pd50 and Co37Pd63 (at.%) alloys exposed to some O-contg. probe mols., i.e. CO, O2 and N2O at 300 K. In addn., XPS was used to elucidate the variation of electronic properties of Co and Pd upon alloying. The studied alloy surfaces proved to be active in dissociative chemisorption of O2 and N2O as well as in the chemisorption of mol. CO. The desorption measurements revealed that CO mols. were less tightly bound to these surfaces than to the individual metals. This observation suggests an electronic interaction between Co and Pd atoms in the alloy, as evidenced by XPS measurements for core and valence bands. N2O decompn. process resulted only in mol. N2, which promptly desorbed, and O atoms, which remained at the surface, poisoning further N2O adsorption by a site blocking mechanism. Amt. of desorbing O mols. significantly depended on the exposure of both O2 and N2O adsorbates and the Co surface concn. (an ensemble compn. effect).

Nanoscaled Metal Borides and Phosphides: Recent Developments and Perspectives
Carenco, Sophie; Portehault, David; Boissiere, Cedric; Mezailles, Nicolas; Sanchez, Clement

A review. The wide variety of nanostructured metal boride and metal phosphide nanoparticles that can be obtained nowadays, and the strategies that researchers successfully developed to reach these nanoscaled phases are summarized. The development of nanoscaled metal borides is clearly less mature essentially for two reasons: the lack of highly reactive boron sources and the resistance to crystn. While mechanistic studies could shed light on the crucial exptl. levers for better compositional, structural, and morphol. control of nanostructured metal phosphides and metal borides, another tantalizing approach is to rethink the existing syntheses in terms of precursors, in an attempt to rationalize the stoichiometry introduced and the reaction temp. The use of single-source precursors provides an interesting soln. by bringing the constituents in the right stoichiometry and already intertwined at the mol. scale. A third path is to use very reactive P or B sources to ensure a quant. incorporation in the final nanomaterials. The two families of materials are not mirrored in this aspect since elemental phosphorus P4 is highly reactive while elemental boron allotropes are very stable. Relying on specific reaction media that can enhance kinetics, like specific solvents (e.g., salt melts) for metal borides, is another tempting soln. The properties of nanoscaled metal borides and metal phosphides are shown to differ, if not outperform in some cases, those of the traditional bulk phases because of increased surface exposure or grain boundary d., and also confinement, like quantum effects in semiconductors. The behavior of these nanoscaled cryst. phases in electronics, optics, magnetism, mechanics, and biomedicine are still to be explored, esp. because most of these compds. have not been obtained yet at the nanoscale in the strict sense: one particle dimension below 100 nm. Future works may then first conc. on a better rationalization of the synthetic procedures, in order to further develop applications, for instance in the field of catalysis.

Theory of bonding of transition metals to nontransition metals
Gelatt, C. D., Jr.; Williams, A. R.; Moruzzi, V. L.
Physical Review B: Condensed Matter and Materials Physics
(
1983

A theory is given of the chem. bond in compds. consisting of both transition metals and nontransition metals. Chem. trends in the bonding properties were established by directly comparing the total energies of a large no. of such compds. with the total energies of their constituents. These chem. trends were analyzed in terms of the s-,p-, and d-like state densities of the compds. and the constituents. Rather different types of bonding result when the at. s and p levels of the nontransition metal lie above, below, and near the energy of the transition-metal d level. The heat of compd. formation results from a competition between the two simple phys. effects: (1) the weakening of the transition-metal bonds by the lattice dilatation required for the accommodation of the nontransition metal, and (2) the increased bonding that results from the occupation of the bonding members of the hybrid states formed from the interaction between the transition-metal d states and the s-p states of the nontransition metal. The theor. values for the heats of formation of these compds. are generally similar to those given by the Miedema empirical formula. Distinctive aspects of the variation of the heat of formation with the no. of valence electrons reveal, however, that the microscopic picture on which the empirical formula is based is quite different from that given by the present self-consistent energy-band theory.

Highly efficient and durable catalysts are increasingly sought in water electrolysis, particularly for resolving the sluggish oxygen evolution reaction (OER) kinetics. Herein, ternary phosphides in the palladium-nickel-phosphorus system developed via a simple redn. approach as hollow and dense nanostructures (PdNiP-H and PdNiP-D, resp.) are shown to overcome the kinetic drawbacks of Pd and deliver superior alk. OER activity. The PdNiP-H showed OER activity at a significantly lower overpotential (300 mV) and Tafel slope (48 mV dec-1) in addn. to having a longer stability than the corresponding dense particles (PdNiP-D) (330 mV and 49 mV dec-1) and the com. benchmark, RuO2 (360 mV and 67 mV dec-1), in half-cell conditions. While combining expts. and d. functional theory (DFT) calcns., these enhancements are shown to arise from surface properties and the modified electronic environment of the ternary phosphide as well as by the enhanced charge transfer sites due to the hollow architecture. DFT calcns. identify the d. of states (DOS) and support Pd lattice alteration, the shift in the d band center, and the subsequent modification in electronic properties of Pd that is favorable for OER. The phosphodization methodol. adopted here highlights an efficient strategy for generating a range of morphologies of ternary phosphides as sustainable and stable energy conversion/storage materials.

Direct formate fuel cells (DFFCs) are a promising clean energy conversion system in operating portable devices. However, their practicability is currently challenging due to the absence of superior anion ionomers. In this respect, the anion ionomer-free electrode structures can be a good alternative for DFFCs. Herein, DFFCs are fabricated employing cation ionomers and anion exchange membranes in the configuration of membrane-electrode assemblies. The electrode structures are optimized through variation of the ionomer proportions in the catalyst layers. As a result, the ionomer content of 10 wt% for both the anode and cathode shows mech. stable operation. On the other hand, the ionomer content of 5 and 10 wt% for the anode and cathode shows the highest performance of 191 mW cm-2, but it shows mech. instability. These optimizations demonstrate that there are different optimal points depending on the ionomer content concerning the cell performance and mech. cell stability during the cell operation, which is mainly attributed to the difference in electrochem. active surface area and phys. stability of the electrode structures. Furthermore, the difference in accessibility of liq. fuels to the electrodes depending on the fuel concns. has an influence on the cell resistance and is elucidated based on the water-in-salt concept.

Pd nanoparticles supported on SiO2, Si3N4 and Al2O3 were studied to examine the effect of particle size and support type on the hydrogenation of 1,3-butadiene. Pd nanoparticles were produced using a reverse micelle method resulting in particles with a remarkably small particle size distribution (σ < < 1 nm). The support type and particle size were obsd. to affect both catalytic activity and product selectivity. All catalysts showed a decrease of their activity with time on stream, paired with an increase in selectivity to butenes (1-butene and cis/trans-2-butene) from a product stream initially dominated by n-butane. In situ XAFS demonstrated a correlation between the formation of palladium hydride and n-butane prodn. in the early stages (∼ 1 h) of reaction. The extent of palladium hydride formation, as well as its depletion with time on stream, was dependent on both particle size and support type. Metallic Pd was identified as the species selective towards the prodn. of butenes.

A review. Direct formate fuel cells (DFFC), which convert the chem. energy stored in formate directly into electricity, are recently attracting more attention, primarily because of the use of the carbon-neutral fuel and the low-cost electrocatalytic and membrane materials. As an emerging energy technol., the DFFC has made a rapid progress in recent years (currently, the state-of-the-art power d. is 591 mW cm-2 at 60 °C). This article provides a review of past research on the development of this type of fuel cell, including the working principle, mechanisms and materials of the electrocatalytic oxidn. of formate, singe-cell designs and performance, as well as innovative system designs. In addn., future perspectives with regard to the development of this fuel cell system are also highlighted.

A direct formate fuel cell (DFFC) operated with a fuel of alk. potassium formate has been studied using Pd anode and Ag cathode electrocatalysts in an intermediate temp. range of 80 to 120 °C by means of cyclic voltammetry and single cell measurements. Voltammetric studies clearly show that the kinetics of the formate electrooxidn. on Pd in alk. media is substantially increased with increasing temp., leading to a high apparent activation energy of around 74.3 ± 6.2 kJ mol- 1. Preliminary single cell measurements show that increasing operating temp. and the formate concn. obviously increase the performance. A DFFC operated with 6 mol dm- 3 HCOOK and at 120 °C demonstrates a peak power d. of around 160 mW cm- 2 over a c.d. range of 250 to 550 mA cm- 2 without Ohmic resistance correction. The DFFC is therefore a promising high performance, environmentally benign and low cost fuel cell technol.

Anodic and catalytic oxidns. of formate ion at an active Pd electrode were studied by the potential-sweep and the galvanostatic methods in connection with the measurements of the rate of formation of H on Pd during the catalytic decompn. of formate. A Pd surface oxidized by pre-anodization is reduced with ease by dissolved formate. Formate adsorbed on the cleaned surface decomp. into 2 fragments such as Had and CO-2ad through the reaction HCO2- → Had + CO-2ad. On standing, CO-2ad is oxidized further by OH- to CO32- and Had. In the absence of polarization, the net reaction of the catalytic decompn. is HCO2- + OH- → CO32- + 2Had. Presence of Had on Pd hinders this reaction to some extent, but H evolution was observed at high electrolyte concns. The net reaction of anodic oxidn. of formate is HCO2- + 3OH- → CO32- + 2H2O + 2 e, in which reactions such as Had + OH- → H2O + e and CO-2ad + 2 OH- → CO32- + H2O + e are involved. The nature of the open-circuit voltage in this system is examd. by taking these species into consideration.

The effect of Zn addn. on the Pd turnover rate (TOR) for the H2O-gas shift (WGS) reaction was studied for 2% Pd on alumina with Zn content varying from 0 to 19% Zn by wt. Over 85% of the Zn reacted with alumina to form Zn aluminate with a fraction reacting with Pd. The av. Pd-Zn coordination no. as measured by EXAFS increased monotonically from 0 to 4.5 as the Zn loading on alumina increased. At a loading of 2% Pd and 19% Zn on alumina the molar fraction of Zn in the Pd particles was 0.34, and the turnover rate increased by a factor of 13, as compared with the pure metallic Pd supported on alumina, to 3.6 × 10-2 mol H2 s-1 (mol exposed Pd)-1 at 280°, 6.8% CO, 8.5% CO2, 21.9% H2O and 37.4% H2 at 1 atm. The formation of the ordered 1:1 PdZn intermetallic compd. by deposition of Pd on Zn oxide increased the av. Pd-Zn coordination no. to 5.9 and the WGS turnover rate by a factor of 20 to 5.3 × 10-2 mol H2 s-1 (mol exposed Pd)-1. The bonding of adsorbed CO changed from 80% bridging on pure Pd to 90% linear on the 1:1 PdZn intermetallic compd. as detd. by diffuse reflectance IR spectroscopy performed under WGS conditions. The fraction of CO binding linearly to Pd correlated linearly with the WGS rate per Pd on the surface. Because the dispersion of the samples was about the same, this result implies that the no. of active sites can be counted by the fraction of CO binding linearly. A simple random substitution model for PdZn distribution was used to est. the concn. of Pd and Zn on the surface, based on the coordination nos. measured by EXAFS. The correlation of the reaction rate with the types of sites on catalysts with 6 different Pd-Zn compns. shows that the data is consistent with an active site composed of surface Pd atoms with surface coordination to 2 Pd and 4 Zn atoms, which is the coordination expected for the (111) plane of the 1:1 PdZn intermetallic compd. An alternate explanation for the promotional effect of Zn on Pd/alumina is that the formation of Zn aluminate inhibits the deleterious Pd-alumina interaction.

Gao, Feng; Goodman, D. Wayne

Royal Society of Chemistry

A review. Pd-Au bimetallic catalysts often display enhanced catalytic activities and selectivities compared with Pd-alone catalysts. This enhancement is often caused by two alloy effects, i.e., ensemble and ligand effects. The ensemble effect is a diln. of surface Pd by Au. With increasing surface Au coverage, contiguous Pd ensembles disappear and isolated Pd ensembles form. For certain reactions, for example vinyl acetate synthesis, this effect is responsible for reaction rate enhancement via the formation of highly active surface sites, e.g., isolated Pd pairs. The disappearance of contiguous Pd ensembles also switches off side reactions catalyzed by these sites. This explains the selectivity increase of certain reactions, for example direct H2O2 synthesis. The ligand effects are electronic perturbation of Pd by Au. Via direct charge transfer or by affecting bond lengths, the ligand effects cause the Pd d band to be more filled, moving the d-band center away from the Fermi level. Both changes make Pd more "at. like" therefore binding reactants and products more weakly. For certain reactions, this eliminates a so-called "self-poisoning" effect and enhances activity/selectivity.

CO tolerance of pure Pt, Pt-Co, and Pt-Ru alloys was studied by XPS combined with an electrochem. cell (EC-XPS) to design better anode catalysts. After electrochem. stabilization and/or CO adsorption the electrodes were transferred to the XPS chamber without exposure to air to avoid contamination of the surfaces. Alloying with Co or Ru modified the electronic structure of Pt atoms resulting in a pos. core level (CL) shift of Pt 4f7/2 which can weaken the Pt-CO interaction. For the Pt-Co alloy electrode the Pt 4f7/2 CL shift remained after electrochem. stabilization despite Co dissoln. and formation of a Pt layer. Changes in surface core level shifts (ΔSCLSs) induced by CO adsorption were evaluated and related to the CO adsorption energy. The values of ΔSCLS at these alloys were smaller than that of pure Pt, indicating that Ru and Co are effective elements to weaken the bond strength of Pt-CO.

Pd-Cu/C and Pd/C catalysts were synthesized via a metal salt redn. method. Phys., chem., and electrochem. characterizations of these two catalysts were compared and used to understand the impact of copper on the palladium surface during the electrochem. oxidn. of formate and ethanol in alk. media. Cyclic voltammetry and chronoamperometry display an enhanced oxidn. rate and stability for Pd-Cu/C alloy catalyst toward formate and ethanol in alk. media when compared to Pd/C catalyst. The authors demonstrate herein two important features of a Pd87Cu13/C electrocatalyst that indicate it is a more efficient catalyst in alk. media than Pd/C for the electrochem. oxidn. of three polyalcs.: ethylene glycol, propylene glycol, and glycerol. First, the authors discovered more efficient behavior in a three electrode electrochem. cell, where the electrochem. oxidn. rate of ethylene glycol and propylene glycol was 4 times faster on Pd87Cu13/C than Pd/C. In glycerol, the oxidn. rate was 3 times faster in the electrochem. cell. This increase in oxidn. rate is due to a combination of the electronic and bifunctional effects. Second, the Pd87Cu13/C catalyst is also more efficient than Pd/C in an operating alk. direct liq. fuel cell, although the efficiency gains are smaller than the electrochem. cell. During fuel cell testing, the max. power d. of a propylene glycol fuel cell was 86% greater when the anode catalyst was Pd-Cu/C compared with Pd/C. The max. power densities of the glycerol and ethylene glycol fuel cells increased by 75% and 32%, resp. These polyalc. mols. are of significant interest because they can be made from renewable sources and used to produce power in alk. direct liq. fuel cells.

Formate is the one legitimate carbon-neutral fuel that has the capability of being considered an alternative to alc. fuels amidst the growing demand for efficient fuel-cell systems. In this manuscript, it is demonstrated, for the first time, a class of binary Pd-Ni alloy nanoparticles over two different carbon supports showing exceptional enhancement of the formate oxidn. reaction (FOR) performance in alk. medium, compared to Pd/C. The synergistic effects of Pd and oxophilic Ni along with the electronic structure alteration of Pd induced through alloying resulted in an effective change in its catalytic ability, leading to a 5-time enhancement in the overall c.d. along with a lower overpotential during formate oxidn. compared to Pd/C. The more active Pd catalytic sites of the nanoalloy helped to yield mass activities as high as 4.5 A mg-1Pd and 7.8 A mg-1Pd during FOR. The structural and electrochem. anal. justifies the synergistic effects and alterations in the Pd lattice ensuing a superior enhancement of electrochem. active Pd sites.

In this paper, we report the prepn. of a highly active and durable ordered intermetallic PdFe catalyst supported on carbon black for formic acid oxidn. reaction (FAOR) by high-temp. heat treatment under a reductive atm. We found that the ordered intermetallic PdFe catalyst exhibited considerably better catalytic activity and durability toward FAOR than the disordered PdFe and pure Pd catalysts because of the high alloying degree between Pd and Fe, which induced a downshift of the Pd d-band center and structural modifications that formed a superlattice cryst. structure with Pd surface segregation. We analyzed the improved catalytic properties of the ordered intermetallic PdFe catalyst through various electrochem. analyses such as cyclic voltammetry, CO oxidn. methods, chronoamperometry, physicochem. analyses such as XPS, and synchrotron radiation methods such as X-ray absorption spectroscopy. D. functional theory calcn. verified the improved FAOR activity of the ordered intermetallic PdFe catalyst. In addn., a single cell based on the ordered intermetallic PdFe catalyst was also fabricated and exhibited enhanced cell performance compared to those based on the other catalysts. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study on the prepn. of an ordered intermetallic PdFe catalyst for FAOR with real single-cell application in direct formic acid fuel cells (DFAFCs). We believe that our results will be helpful for the development of highly active and durable Pd alloy catalysts for FAOR and the commercialization of DFAFC.
